title: Harry S. Truman is greeted by Randall Jessee
Scopenote: Former President Harry S. Truman is greeted by Randall Jessee, WDAF television newsman, at his home in Independence as he begins his morning walk.  From:  Copied from original photographs loaned to the library by Harry Barth.  Originals were returned to Mr. Barth.

title: 1947 Studebaker Champion DeLuxe coupe at Truman home
Scopenote: 1947 Studebaker Champion DeLuxe 3 passenger coupe (business coupe) parked behind the Truman home in Independence. The car does not belong to President Truman.  From:  Copied from original photographs loaned to the library by Harry Barth.  Originals were returned to Mr. Barth.

title: 1947 Studebaker coupe at Truman home
Scopenote: 1947 Studebaker Champion DeLuxe 3 passenger coupe (business coupe)parked behind the Truman home in Independence. It is not a car that belongs to President Truman.  From:  Copied from original photographs loaned to the library by Harry Barth.  Originals were returned to Mr. Barth.

title: President Ronald Reagan speaks at Santa-Cali-Gon days
Scopenote: President Ronald Reagan speaks at Santa-Cali-Gon Days celebration in Independence, Missouri, as First Lady Nancy Reagan (left) watches. From: Copied from original photographs loaned to the library by Harry Barth. Originals were returned to Mr. Barth.

title: President Ronald Reagan speaks at Santa-Cali-Gon days in Independence
Scopenote: President Ronald Reagan speaks at Santa-Cali-Gon days celebration in Independence, Missouri.   From:  Copied from original photographs loaned to the library by Harry Barth.  Originals were returned to Mr. Barth.

title: Damaged buildings in Berlin, Germany, after World War II
Scopenote: A street in Berlin, Germany, showing buildings damaged or destroyed by bombing in World War II.  Donor:  Barney Ricketts.

title: Portrait of General Dwight D. Eisenhower
Scopenote: Portrait of General Dwight D. Eisenhower with troops in background.  From:  Copied from original photographs loaned to the library by Harry Barth.  Originals were returned to Mr. Barth.

title: President Dwight Eisenhower visits Kansas City
Scopenote: President Dwight D. Eisenhower and First Lady Mamie Eisenhower depart airplane at Municipal Airport in Kansas City.    From:  Copied for original photographs loaned to the library by Harry Barth.  Originals were returned to Mr. Barth.

title: President Dwight Eisenhower visits Kansas City
Scopenote: President Dwight D. Eisenhower and First Lady Mamie Eisenhower depart airplane at Municipal Airport in Kansas City.  From:  Copied from original photographs loaned to the library by Harry Barth.  Originals were returned to Mr. Barth.

title: President Dwight Eisenhower visits Kansas City
Scopenote: President Dwight D. Eisenhower standing by presidential airplane at Municipal Airport in Kansas City.  Others are unidentified.  From:  Copied from original photographs loaned to the library by Harry Barth.  Originals were returned to Mr. Barth.

title: President Dwight Eisenhower and grandson, David, visit Kansas City
Scopenote: President Dwight D. Eisenhower and grandson, David Eisenhower, depart presidential airplane at Kansas City Municipal Airport.  From:  Copied from original photographs loaned to the library by Harry Barth.  Originals were returned to Mr. Barth.

title: President Dwight Eisenhower and grandson, David, visit Kansas City
Scopenote: President Dwight D. Eisenhower and grandson, David Eisenhower, depart presidential airplane at Kansas City Municipal Airport.  From:  Copied from original photographs loaned to the library by Harry Barth.  Originals were returned to Mr. Barth.

title: President Dwight Eisenhower visits Kansas City
Scopenote: President Dwight Eisenhower at Municipal Airport in Kansas City.  Grandson David Eisenhower is in the automobile.    From:  Copied from original photographs loaned to the library by Harry Barth.  Originals were returned to Mr. Barth.

title: President Dwight Eisenhower visits Kansas City
Scopenote: President Dwight D. Eisenhower helps his granddaughter into the automobile at Kansas City Municipal Airport. Others are unidentified. From: Copied from original photographs loaned to the library by Harry Barth. Originals were returned to Mr. Barth.

title: World's only airlifted pontoon bridge, Korean War
Scopenote: Far East Air Forces Combat Cargo Command Airlift Airbase, Japan. Rolling across the world's only airlifted pontoon bridge, are these veteran U. S. Eighth Army Troops.  Airlifted from Japan by huge troop carrier aircraft of Feafs Combat Cargo Command, this bridge has become the key crossing point on the Han River where United Nations Forces are driving north in pursuit of North Korean Reds.  Three bridges which had previously spanned the Han, were completely destroyed by Air Force, Navy and Marine Fighter Bombers.  Note that American G.I.'s have taken up temporary light housekeeping in some of the spacious aluminum alloy pontoons.  This is a portion of the bridge lifted in the OPN.

title: Russian hand grenades found during Korean War
Scopenote: Boxes of Russian hand grenades taken north of Seoul, Korea, during the Korean War.

title: Buildings in Berlin, Germany, damaged by bombing in World War II
Scopenote: On a Sunday afternoon, German civilians stroll across a town square in Berlin.  In the background are buildings damaged or destroyed by bombing in World War II.  Donor:  Barney Ricketts.

title: American C-54 Military Aircraft burning
Scopenote: An American C-54 Military Aircraft burns on a South Korean landing strip after being strafed by Communist North Korean fighters.

title: General Douglas MacArthur and members of his staff
Scopenote: General of the Army Douglas MacArthur (center) and members of his staff appraise the terrain conditions near Seoul, Korea.  The general flew from his Tokyo headquarters of make an on the spot appraisal of the situation developing in the communist North Korean invasion of the South Korean Republic.

title: United States ground troops to Korea
Scopenote: Ground troops of the United States Army board a transport plane at a Japanese Air Base for shipment to Korea.

title: First American Soldier Killed in Korean War, in Action near Osan
Scopenote: Members of the 24th Infantry Division, first United States ground units to reach the front, go into action against North Korean forces at the village of Sojong-Ni, near Osan.  At right is Private First Class Kenneth Shadrick, who was killed by enemy fire a few moments after this photo was made, thus becoming the first United States soldier to die in the Korean campaign.

title: United States gun crew fires 105 Howitzer during Korean War
Scopenote: United States gun crew fires 105 Howitzer gun in action against the Communist led North Korean invaders, somewhere in Korea.

title: American soldier of the 21st Infantry Regiment
Scopenote: One of four American soldiers of the 21st Infantry Regiment, 24th Division, company unknown, found midway between the forward observation post and the actual front line.  Cameraman's caption states that the men were probably captured the night of July 9th and then shot.  Most of them were shot through the head with their arms tied behind their backs.  Along with them was a variety of equipment burned and destroyed.

title: Enemy tanks captured by United States troops during Korean War
Scopenote: Enemy tanks captured by United States troops from Communist led North Korean invaders, somewhere in Korea.

title: Destroyer Escort U. S. S. Higby and U. S. S. Mt. McKinley during Korean War
Scopenote: Destroyer Escort U. S. S. Higby comes alongside U. S. S. Mt. McKinley to pass message dropped by Navy Plane enroute to Korea.

title: Men of the First Cavalry Division go ashore in Korea
Scopenote: Men of the First Cavalry Division go ashore from landing craft somewhere in Korea. Same as 67-7292.

title: American Jeep with ammunition during Korean War
Scopenote: An American Jeep with ammunition for a unit of the 1st Cavalry Division, breaks through sniper fire as army engineers lay down a barrage of small arms fire to pin the snipers down, during the Korean War.

title: An Russian soldier watches German citizens on a street in Berlin, Germany, after World War II
Scopenote: A armed Russian soldier leans against a pillar and watches citizens walking on a street in Berlin, Germany,  In the background are buildings damaged by bombing in World War II.  Donor:  Barney Ricketts.

title: Navy Panther Jet prepares to take off from carrier during Korean War
Scopenote: A Navy Panther Jet prepares to take off from the deck of a carrier operating somewhere off the coast of Korea.

title: Private First Class Clair Wagner, Corporal Lester Tichenor, Private Clem Boody and Private Thomas Hammond in Korea
Scopenote: Left to right:  Private First Class Clair Wagner, McClure, Pennsylvania; Corporal Lester Tichenor, Worthington, West Virginia; Private Clem Boody, Chicago, Illinois; and Private Thomas Hammond, Washington, D. C. install a line at communication center somewhere in Korea.

title: United States Soldier wounded in action in Korean War
Scopenote: United States Soldier wounded in action against the North Korean forces in the Pohang-Dong area, is transferred from tank to Jeep to be taken to medical aid station behind the lines.

title: Grief stricken American infantryman comforted by another soldier
Scopenote: An unidentified grief stricken American infantryman whose buddy has been killed in action is comforted by another soldier, Tolbert Raymond Winchester.  In the background, a corpsman methodically fills out casualty tags.  Haktong-Ni area, Korea.

title: Medics carry wounded during Korean War
Scopenote: Medics carry back wounded of the 5th RCT, hit in attack on Chuk, Chon Mountain in the Masan area during the Korean War.

title: Sergeant First Class David K. Brood
Scopenote: Tired and covered with the grime of war after forty-three straight days on the front lines, Sergeant First Class David K. Brood (Laif, Oahu, T. H.) of the 5th RCT, stops to take a load off his feet.

title: Sergeant First Class Al Chang by Tank
Scopenote: Sergeant First Class Al Chang (Honolulu, T. H.) combat photographer of the "A" Company, 71st Signal Sv Bn GHQ, Tokyo, Japan, leans against the rear of an American M-4 Tank, getting a moments rest before the unit he is covering goes into another attack.  Sergeant First Class Chang has been covering the front line in Korea, pictorially, constantly since he first arrived in Korea over six weeks ago.

title: Amtrac Borne members of the 1st Marine Division Attack at Inchon
Scopenote: Amtrac Borne members of the 1st Marine Division head for "Blue Beach" on Wolmi Island, Inchon Harbor, as the first strike to secure, for United Nations forces, this vital Communist supply port.

title: General Douglas MacArthur and members of his staff during Korean War
Scopenote: General Douglas MacArthur (seated) Commander in Chief, United Nations forces in Korea, and members of his staff view pre-landing bombardment and air strikes from the flag bridge of the U.S.S. Mt. McKinley in Korean waters off Inchon, as United Nations forces begin their offensive in that section.  Left to right:  Brigadier General Courtney Whitney, Chief, Government Section GHQ Scap; General MacArthur; Brigadier General E. K. Wright, Assistant Chief of Staff, G-3 Section, GHQ FEC; and Major General Edward M. Almond, CG X Corps.

title: Colonel L. G. Puller, General Douglas MacArthur, Major General O. P. Smith and Vice Admiral Arthur D. Struble
Scopenote: Colonel L. B. Puller, First Marine Division; General of the Army Douglas MacArthur, Commander in Chief United Nations Forces in Korea; Major General O. P. Smith, CG First Marine Division; and Vice Admiral Arthur D. Struble, Commander Joint Task Force Seven, accompanied by staff officers and newsmen, observe action from a hill overlooking the 1st Marine Regimental front.

title: Buildings in Berlin showing damage from bombing in World War II
Scopenote: German citizens conduct their business on a street in Berlin, Germany, lined with buildings damaged or destroyed by bombing in World War II.  Donor:  Barney Ricketts.

title: General Douglas MacArthur attends a briefing session during Korean War
Scopenote: General Douglas MacArthur, Commander in Chief, United Nations Forces in Korea, attends a briefing session at the 1st Marine Division Headquarters, Inchon, Korea.

title: General of the Army Douglas MacArthur and staff officers
Scopenote: General of the Army Douglas MacArthur, Commander in Chief of United Nations Forces in Korea, accompanied by staff officers, visit a Prisoner of War camp at Inchon, Korea.

title: Prisoners of War in Korea
Scopenote: On their way to a prison camp, prisoners of war are marched past a knocked out T-34 tank, east of Inchon, Korea.

title: Men of the 5th RCT in Korean War
Scopenote: Men of the 5th RCT fire on the enemy along the Nakdong River, north of Taegu, Korea.

title: ROK Marines during Korean War
Scopenote: ROK Marines arrive across the Han River on the way to Seoul, Korea.

title: United Nations troops in Korean War
Scopenote: United Nations troops fighting in the streets of Seoul, Korea.
Source Photographer: Robert L. Strickland and John Romanowski

title: United Nations troops during Korean War
Scopenote: United Nations troops fighting on the outskirts of Seoul, the capital of Korea, during the Korean War.
Source Photographer: Robert L. Strickland and John Romanowski

title: United Nations Troops in Seoul
Scopenote: United Nations troops fighting in the streets of Seoul, capital of Korea, during Korean War.

title: AMTPAC's of the 1st Marine Division on Han River
Scopenote: AMTPAC's of the 1st Marine Division come out of the Han River at the Ahengju River crossing on the Korean battle line.

title: Men of First Cavalry Division, crossing Nakdong River near Taejon, Korea
Scopenote: Men of the 5th RCT, 1st Cavalry Division use a shallow boat to cross the Nakdong River as they advance against North Korean forces near Taejon, Korea.

title: A street in Berlin, Germany, lined with buildings damaged or destroyed in World War II
Scopenote: A view down a street in Berlin, Germany, looking toward the Victory Column commemorating an 1871 war, lined on both sides with buildings destroyed or damaged by bombing in World War II.  Donor:  Barney Ricketts.

title: Opening ceremony to restore the capitol, Seoul, to the Republic of Korea
Scopenote: Opening ceremony to restore the capitol, Seoul, to the Republic of Korea; General Douglas MacArthur, Commanding General, United Nations Forces in Korea, leads the Lord's Prayer.

title: Sixteen inch guns of the U. S. S. Missouri fire at North Korean enemy military targets in Chongjin, Korea
Scopenote: Sixteen inch guns of the U. S. S. Missouri fire at North Korean enemy military targets in Chongjin, Korea.

title: First Chinese Communists captured by the 1st ROK Corps
Scopenote: First Chinese Communists captured by the 1st ROK Corps, 30KM outside of Hamhung, Korea.  They are also the first Chinese to fight the United Nations forces in Korea.

title: Chaplain Riddle Conducts Thanksgiving Day Services During Korean War
Scopenote: With a Jeep for an altar and Manchurian Hills for a backdrop, Chaplain Burgess P. Riddle, San Antonio, Texas, conducts Thanksgiving Day Services on the banks of the frozen Yalu River at Hyesanjin.

title: Supplies and equipment are evacuated during Korean War
Scopenote: Supplies and equipment are also evacuated from the onslaught of the Communist forces bearing down on Hungham, Korea.

title: Docks at Hungham, Korea are destroyed by United Nations forces
Scopenote: Docks at Hungham, Korea are destroyed by United Nations forces as they are forced to evacuate that area.

title: United Nations forces advance against enemy during Korean War
Scopenote: Elements of the 35th Infantry Regiment, 25th Infantry Division, advance over mountains north of Osan, Korea, as the United Nations forces push north on the western front, during action against the Chinese Communist aggressors in that area.

title: M-4 tanks of the 89th Tank Company, 25th Infantry Division
Scopenote: M-4 tanks of the 89th Tank Company, 25th Infantry Division, supporting troops of the 35th Infantry Regiment, 25th Infantry Division, move through the burning town of Osan, Korea, during push of the United Nations forces against the Chinese Communist aggressors in that area.

title: Air support in action
Scopenote: Men of the 8th Cavalry Regiment, 1st Cavalry Division, watch an aircraft hit enemy positions on their flank with Napalm and strafing runs near Yangzi, Korea.

title: Corporal Angelo Soprano leans over cliff to fasten jumper during Korean War
Scopenote: Corporal Angelo Soprano, Sayre, Pennsylvania, leans dangerously over cliff to fasten jumper. He is in the first platoon, A Company, 4th Signal Bn. They are rehabilitating lines from Tanyang to Chechon, Korea.

title: Buildings near Kaiserstrasse in Berlin, Germany, damaged by bombing during World War II
Scopenote: Buildings near Kaiserstrasse in Berlin, Germany, damaged or destroyed by bombing during World War II. Donor: Barney Ricketts.

title: Corporal James E. Gilman and Sergeant Tony F. Haluska search a Korean refugee for weapons
Scopenote: Just outside the village of Anungmyan-Ni, eighteen miles northeast of Wonju, Korea, Corporal James E. Gilman, Oblong, Illinois, (left) and Sergeant Tony F. Haluska, Clifton, New Jersey, (right) both of the 3rd BN, 187th A/B RCT, 8th United States Army, search a Korean refugee for weapons or other contraband.

title: Troops advance against enemy in Korean War
Scopenote: Platoon leader contacts headquarters by radio as elements of Company "B" 27th Infantry Regiment, 25th Infantry Division advance against the Chinese Communist enemy forces near Anyang-Ni, Korea.

title: Heading off flank drive during Korean War
Scopenote: 3rd BN, 187th RCT (ABRN) moves east of Pambol-Ni, Korea, 25 miles northeast of Wonju to head off flanking movement by enemy troops.

title: POW's released by Chinese Communists during Korean War
Scopenote: Warming up before a stove in the 24th Division Medical Clearing Station after being returned to United States lines by Chinese Communists, former prisoners of war are, left to right:  Private First Class Robert B. Duncan, Dayton, Ohio; Private First Class Joseph A. Collins, Selmer, North Carolina; Corporal Lawrence Buckland,  Sidney, Australia; Lieutenant Angus MacDonald, Brisbane, Australia (both of the British 27th Brigade); and 1st Lieutenant George E. Dowrie, Brunswick, Georgia.

title: Soldiers check for broken communication lines in Korea
Scopenote: Men of the 7th Signal Company, 7th Infantry Division check for broken communication lines south of Pyongyang, Korea.

title: Signal operations in Korea
Scopenote: Corporal William Lindsey, Jr., Teaneck, New Jersey (left) and Corporal Roger D. Butler, Wellboro, Pennsylvania (right), members of the 24th Signal Company, 24th Infantry Division, string communication lines in captured village of Yangkyung, Korea.

title: Forward observer John Mellon during Korean War
Scopenote: 1st Lieutenant John Mellon, Tapentum, Pennsylvania, K Company, 32nd RCT, 7th Division, helps heavy mortar and artillery crews zero in enemy positions on hill north east of Cwae-Jaf, Korea, which his company is about to attack.

title: Signal equipment in Tokyo during Korean War
Scopenote: Telephone equipment terminal and repeater vans at 71st Signal SV BN, General Headquarters, Far East Command, Tokyo, Japan. This photo was taken during the occupation of Japan, and the Korean War.

title: Radio equipment during Korean War
Scopenote: Components of AN/GRC-26 full-duplex mobile radio teletype equipment frequency shifter is shown on upper shelf, 400 watt transmitter is at right.  Equipment is at 71st Signal SV BN, Tokyo, Japan, during the Korean War.

title: Radio equipment during Korean War
Scopenote: Left inside view of truck containing mobile radio teletype equipment AN/GRC-26, receivers for diversity reception in rear, storage bins for spare parts at left, during Korean War.

title: Buildings along Bismarchstrasse in Berlin, Germany, damaged by bombing in World War II
Scopenote: A view along Bismarchstrasse in Berlin, Germany, showing buildings damaged or destroyed by bombing in World War II. On the left is a memorial statue of Queen Victoria. Donor: Barney Ricketts.

title: Telephone switchboard during Korean War
Scopenote: Twelve position switchboard, TC-10, mounted in communications van.  Manufactured by Japanese manufacturer for United States 8th Army, under supervision of Signal Section, General Headquarters, Far East Command, during the Korean War.

title: Telephone switchboard during Korean War
Scopenote: Twelve position switchboard, TC-10, mounted in communications van.  Manufactured by Japanese manufacturer for United States 8th Army, under supervision of SIG Section, General Headquarters, Far East Command.

title: Mobile teletype unit during Korean War
Scopenote: Interior of a mobile teletype truck built by men of Company "A". 71st Signal SV BN, Construction and Maintenance Section, Communication Division, Tokyo, Japan.  This vehicle will be put into operation in the Korean theater.

title: Mobile teletype unit during Korean War
Scopenote: Exterior view of a mobile teletype truck built by men of Company "A", 71st Signal SV BN, Construction and Maintenance Section, Communication Division, Tokyo, Japan.  This vehicle will be put into operation in the Korean theater.

title: GHC Transmitter and Receiver Equipment in Tokyo
Scopenote: Transmitter Installation, General Headquarters, 71st Signal SVC, BN, Tokyo, Japan.

title: Signal equipment, Tokyo, Japan
Scopenote: An inside view of the transmitter station of General Headquarters, Far East Command at Tokyo, Japan during the Korean War.

title: Communications project in Tokyo
Scopenote: Radio relay in Dai Ichi Building with main frame at far right and EE-101 1000-20 telephone ringing equipment (far left background) is AN/TRC - 1 and AN/TRC - 8 HF radio terminal sets.  Tokyo, Japan.

title: Signal Equipment during Korean War
Scopenote: A view of the radio relay at General Headquarters, Far East Command in Tokyo, Japan, used during the Korean War.

title: General Headquarters Transmitter and Receiver Equipment in Tokyo
Scopenote: Receiver Installation, General Headquarters, 71st Signal SVC, BN, Tokyo, Japan.

title: Communications Center in Japan during Korean War
Scopenote: Receivers AN/FRP3, Receivers Radio Teletype, at Owada, Japan, used during Korean War.

title: Buildings in Berlin, Germany, destroyed or damaged by bombing in World War II
Scopenote: A street in Berlin, Germany, lined with buildings damaged or destroyed by bombing in World War II.  A signed on the left identifies "Rassenhass."  Donor:  Barney Ricketts.

title: Communications Center in Japan
Scopenote: AN/FRPs Receivers Radio Teletype at Owada, Japan, used during Korean War.

title: General Headquarters Communications Center
Scopenote: A CW console of the General Headquarters, Far East Command Communications Center, Dai Ichi Building, Tokyo, Japan.

title: Headquarters Far East Command Communications Center in Tokyo during Korean War
Scopenote: Headquarters in Tokyo, Japan, during Korean War.  Primary ACAN Relay Station UAP.  A portion of the multiple tape preparation console is shown in the left foreground.  Two banks of AN/TGC-1 tape relay units run the entire length of the station.  One of four tape preparation positions utilizing Model 19 Teletypewriters is pictured in the right foreground.  Tape routing racks, supervisor's desks and perforating positions are spaced strategically at three points through the center of the stations.  Soldiers are at work.

title: General Headquarters Communications Center in Tokyo during the Korean War
Scopenote: Relay station of the general headquarters, Far East Command Communications Center, Dai Ichi Building, Tokyo, Japan, during the Korean War.  Soldiers are at work.

title: Communication Center project during Korean War
Scopenote: Corporal Harold P. Stutts, High Point, North Carolina, operating teletypewriter equipment (AN/TGC-1A) at Communication Center Signal Section, General Headquarters, Far East Command.  Equipment is operated by members of 71st SIG SV BN General Headquarters, Far East Command, Tokyo, Japan.

title: Headquarters, Far East Command Communication Center in Tokyo during Korean War
Scopenote: Headquarters, Far East Command Communication Center in Tokyo during Korean War. Multiple address tape preparation console, improvised by station maintenance personnel, utilizes four Model 14 Tape Distributors, six Model 14 Reperforators and one Model 15 Page Printer, plus associated rectifying equipment. This unit is capable of producing duplicate copies of multiple addressed tapes for onward transmission.

title: General Headquarters Communications Center in Tokyo during Korean War
Scopenote: General Headquarters Communications Center, Dai Ichi Building, Tokyo, Japan during Korean War.

title: Headquarters, Far East Command Communications Center in Tokyo during Korean War
Scopenote: Headquarters, Far East Command Communications Center in Tokyo during Korean War.  In and out desk of the terminal.  Messages are logged, routed and dispatched at this point.  The charts in the rear depict the day by day handling time and accuracy level of the station.  The door at the right is the entrance to the cryptocenter.

title: Headquarters, Far East Command Communications Center in Tokyo during Korean War
Scopenote: Headquarters, Far East Command Communications Center in Tokyo during Korean War.  Tape perforation positions.  These four positions utilize Model 19 Teletypewriters for perforating and transmitting outgoing terminal messages into the relay station for onward transmission to addressee.  Soldiers are at work.

title: General Headquarters Communications Center during Korean War
Scopenote: Terminal Station of the General Headquarters, Far East Command Communications Center, Dai Ichi Building, Tokyo, Japan.

title: Former President Harry S. Truman and Mr. and Mrs. Clyde Kimbrough at Fort Lewis, Washington
Scopenote: Former President Harry S. Truman shakes hands with Clyde Kimbrough, standing in a receiving line, who is holding a display of campaign buttons to be presented to Mr. Truman at ceremonies during his visit to Fort Lewis, Washington.  Mrs. Kimbrough is standing next to her husband; the others are unidentified.  Mr. Kimbrough is the principal civilian Post Engineer at the Fort.  From:  Major General Louis W. Truman.

title: Buildings in Berlin, Germany, damaged or destroyed by bombing in World War II
Scopenote: German citizens walk down a street in Berlin where buildings were damaged or destroyed by bombing in World War II.  From:  Barney Ricketts.

title: Headquarters Far East Command Communications Center in Tokyo during Korean War
Scopenote: Interior of General Headquarters teleconference room in Tokyo, Japan, showing conferees' table and projection screens during the Korean War.

title: Headquarters Far East Command Communications Center in Tokyo during Korean War
Scopenote: Headquarters Far East Command Communications Center in Tokyo during Korean War.  Interior of operating section of telecon room showing one of two identical sending and receiving positions.  Standard Model 19 Teletypewriters are used for perforating and sending, while Model 15 Page Copy Printers, without keyboards, are used for receiving.  The Model 14 Reperforator provides a means for monitoring enciphered traffic.

title: Headquarters Far East Command Communications Center in Tokyo during Korean War
Scopenote: Headquarters Far East Command Communications Center in Tokyo, Japan, during the Korean War.  Portion of the teletypewriter repair shop showing work benches and the fixed jigs wired to permit easy test of repaired units during the Korean War.

title: Inspecting the contents of a crate during Korean War
Scopenote: Inspecting the contents of a crate in the reclassification section to determine whether the equipment is Class A or Class C, during Korean War.

title: Unwrapping Class U material during Korean War
Scopenote: Unwrapping Class U material in the reclassifications section during the Korean War.

title: Reclassification Section during Korean War
Scopenote: General view of work in the Reclassification Section, Maintenance Division, 8A Signal Depot during the Korean War.

title: Reclassification Section during Korean War
Scopenote: Opening crates at the Reclassification Section of the Maintenance Division 8A Signal Depot during the Korean War.

title: Signal Maintenance Depot in Yokohama
Scopenote: The equipment cleaning section of the Signal Maintenance Depot, Yokohama, Japan. This was a support center for the Korean War.

title: Signal Maintenance Depot in Yokohama
Scopenote: The crystal shop at the Yokohama, Japan Signal Maintenance Depot. This was a support center for the Korean War.

title: Signal Maintenance Depot in Yokohama
Scopenote: The reconditioning section of the Signal Maintenance Depot, Yokohama, Japan. This was a support center for the Korean War.

title: The Dome in Berlin, Germany, a building destroyed by bombing in World War II
Scopenote: A building called "The Dome" in Berlin, Germany, showing extensive damage from bombing in World War II.  Donor:  Barney Ricketts.

title: Signal Maintenance Depot in Yokohama
Scopenote: The teletype repair section of the Signal Maintenance Depot, Yokohama, Japan. This was a support center for the Korean War.

title: Signal Maintenance Depot in Yokohama
Scopenote: Packaging Facilities at the Yokohama, Japan Signal Maintenance Depot shop. This was a support center for the Korean War.

title: Signal Maintenance Depot in Yokohama
Scopenote: The packaging and packing facilities at the Signal Maintenance Depot, Yokohama, Japan.  This was a support center for the Korean War.

title: Signal Maintenance Depot in Yokohama
Scopenote: The packaging and packing room at the Yokohama, Japan Signal Maintenance Depot. This was a support depot during the Korean War.

title: Signal Maintenance Depot in Yokohama during Korean War
Scopenote: The heavy item packaging and packing line at Yokohama, Japan Signal Maintenance Depot, during the Korean War.  Heavy lifting equipment is available in this area.

title: Rebuilding of signal equipment during Korean War
Scopenote: A Japanese workman cleans and inspects an interior part of a BC-939 Radio Set for defects at Yokohama Repair Shop, Japan, during Korean War.

title: Rebuilding of signal equipment during Korean War
Scopenote: Japanese women applying the final touches of paint to BC-939 radio sets that were rebuilt at the Yokohama, Japan repair shop before they are put in the baking ovens for four hours of baking, during the Korean War.

title: Rebuilding of signal equipment during Korean War
Scopenote: An Army Inspector and a Japanese Inspector make a final check on a rebuilt BC-939 radio set which is a component part of the SCR-399 Mobile Unit.  They are using a BC-610 Transmitter for a tester in the final stage, during the Korean War.

title: Rebuilding of signal equipment during Korean War
Scopenote: A general view of the repair shop in Yokohama, Japan, showing the different types of sets (signal equipment) being worked on, mainly assembly and testing, during the Korean War.

title: Rebuilding of signal equipment during Korean War
Scopenote: A Japanese worker disassembling a RA-34 rectifier in preparation to cleaning, painting and repairing it at the Yokohama, Japan repair shop during the Korean War.

title: Russian soldiers sit on the steps of a memorial to the Kaiser in Berlin
Scopenote: Russian soldiers sit on the steps of a memorial to the Kaiser and on his statue in Berlin, Germany, after the end of World War II.  Some destruction from Allied bombing can be seen at the left of the memorial.  Donor:  Barney Ricketts.

title: Rebuilding of signal equipment during Korean War
Scopenote: A Japanese worker repairing and testing a BC-1000 set in the repair shop at Yokohama, Japan during the Korean War.

title: Rebuilding of signal equipment during Korean War
Scopenote: In the packing room of the Yokohama, Japan repair shop, all the sets are wrapped in waterproof paper and cloth, sealed with heated tar, stenciled and made ready for final boxing in wood boxes during Korean War.

title: Rebuilding of signal equipment during Korean War
Scopenote: The final packing step of the rebuilt signal equipment in wood boxes with excelsior at the Yokohama, Japan repair shop.  The boxes are then baled, stenciled and made ready for shipping for the Korean War.

title: Rebuilding of Signal equipment during Korean War
Scopenote: A Japanese worker is replacing a very delicate hairspring, after polishing it, in a meter for an I-166 at the repair shop in Yokohama, Japan, during the Korean War.

title: Rebuilding of Signal equipment during Korean War
Scopenote: A Japanese technician in Yokohoma testing an S Meter for a BC-779 Transmitter, and using a slide resister and volt and ampere meter during the Korean War.

title: Rebuilding of Signal equipment during Korean War
Scopenote: A plant workroom of the rebuilding repair shop in Yokohama, Japan, where signal equipment is rebuilt during the Korean War.

title: Rebuilding of Signal equipment during Korean War
Scopenote: Testing units, built by the Yokohama Keiki K. K. factory, for testing rebuilt signal equipment during the Korean War.  These duplicate United States meters.

title: Rebuilding Signal Equipment during Korean War
Scopenote: In the packing room of the Yokohama, Japan repair shop, a worker wraps an I-56-K testing set in waterproof paper, then in waterproof metal foil, more waterproof paper and then it is packed with excelsior in a wooden box.

title: Rebuilding of Signal Equipment during Korean War
Scopenote: The packing of rebuilt signal equipment in the final stage during the Korean War.  The seams are carefully sealed with heated tar as shown in the picture.

title: Big signal depot and warehouse on waterfront at Pusan, Korea
Scopenote: Big signal depot and maintenance warehouse located on the waterfront at Pusan, Korea during Korean War.

title: A church in Berlin, Germany, showing extensive damage from bombing in World War II
Scopenote: In Berlin, Germany, a church, showing extensive damage from bombing in World War II, sits on the edge of a lake littered with branches from shredded trees.  Donor:  Barney Ricketts.

title: Radio equipment captured in Korea
Scopenote: Radio equipment captured in Korea, made in Russia in February, 1950.

title: A Japanese-made long line tester captured from North Korean forces
Scopenote: A Japanese-made long line tester captured from North Korean forces.

title: Signal generator, captured from North Korean forces
Scopenote: Japanese-made signal generator captured from North Korean forces.

title: U. N. vehicles cross pontoon bridge near Seoul during the Korean War
Scopenote: Vehicles of United Nations forces cross a pontoon bridge, on the Han River, near Seoul, Korea during the Korean War.

title: Bailey Bridge over Nakdong River in Waegwan, Korea
Scopenote: First vehicles cross the Bailey Bridge, built by 8th army engineers, across the Nakdong River at Waegwan, Korea.

title: Flood waters during Korean War
Scopenote: Brockway Bridge truck of the 3rd Eng. BN, 24th Infantry Division, stuck in washed out dirt road two miles south of Inchon, Korea, is pulled to shore by cable.  The dirt road was destroyed by heavy rainfall in that area.  Object to left of stalled truck is canvas top of jeep that attempted to cross on the road earlier in the day.

title: Bridge at Pyongyang, Korea
Scopenote: Vehicular bridge at Pyongyang, Korea, showing additional construction by I Corps Engineers, providing for two-way traffic.

title: Pontoon bridge destroyed by heavy rains during Korean War
Scopenote: Military Police carry wounded man across gap in pontoon bridge to aid station on other side of the Han River during the Korean War, as workmen continue efforts to repair the bridge which was partially destroyed by heavy rains.

title: Construction of pontoon bridge near Waegwan, Korea during Korean War
Scopenote: Treads are lowered into place on pontoon bridge, constructed by members of 24th Infantry Division Engineer Company near Waegwan, Korea during the Korean War.

title: Large bin covered with tarps near Waegwan, Korea
Scopenote: Large bin covered with tarps near Waegwan, Korea.

title: A bridge in Berlin, Germany, destroyed by bombing in World War II
Scopenote: A street bridge in Berlin, Germany, destroyed by bombing in World War II.  In the background are buildings showing extensive damage.  Donor:  Barney Ricketts.

title: United States troops cut through field in Korea
Scopenote: United States troops cut through field on way to the Nakdong River, during offensive launched against the North Korean energy troops in that area.

title: A mine detector crew clears a field in Waegwan, Korea
Scopenote: A 24th Infantry Division mine detector crew clears a field at Waegwan, Korea.

title: Cpl. Fred M. Grimes digging out wood box mine during Korean War
Scopenote: Corporal Fred M. Grimes, Carbondale, Illinois, digging out wood box mine on the drive to Kumchon, Korea.  In background are photographers of the 24th Infantry Division.

title: Motor grader on road in Korea
Scopenote: Motor grader on road in Korea.

title: Road in Korea
Scopenote: Road in Korea, with tunnel.

title: Dump truck used during road construction in Korea
Scopenote: Dump truck used during road construction in Korea.

title: Bridge construction in Korea
Scopenote: Private First Class Merrill E. Bagley, Waterboro, Maine, of "C" Company, 62nd Engineer Battalion, electro-welds main supports on this temporary rail bridge being constructed across the Han River, Korea.

title: Ferry crossing Nakdong River in Korea
Scopenote: 8th Engineer Battalion operates a ferry across the Nakdong River at Songju, Korea during the Korean War.

title: Bridge being built in Korea
Scopenote: Combat engineers of the 11th Engineer Battalion, I Corps, with the smoke of battle still in view, build a bridge over a river in North Korea.

title: Construction of bridge in Korea
Scopenote: Scene at Waegwan, Korea, as 8th Army Engineers construct Bailey Bridge across the Nakdong River during the Korean War.

title: An air raid shelter in Berlin, Germany, crushed by bombs during World War II
Scopenote: Civilians and the military look over an air raid shelter crushed by bombs during World War II on the Kaiserplatz in Berlin, Germany.  Several destroyed statues litter the street, and in the background are a church and buildings also damaged by the bombing.  Donor:  Barney Ricketts.

title: Destruction of railroad bridge at Hamhung
Scopenote: In order to destroy this railway bridge across the Songchon River at Hamhung, Korea, and delay the advancing Communist Army, a section of the bridge was blown out and a locomotive pushed over the edge of the gap. The crisscrossed wooden ties supporting much of the track were set afire and later the other locomotive and freight car remaining on the bridge were dynamited.

title: Repaired railroad trestle in Korea
Scopenote: Section of repaired railroad trestle between Angahn and Pohang, Korea. This bridge blown up by retreating United Nations Forces during the early part of the conflict, and was repaired by Korean laborers.

title: Destroyed rail bridge in Korea
Scopenote: Korean rail bridge is destroyed by members of the 65th Engineer Battalion, 25th Infantry Division, during the Korean War.

title: Floating bridge in Korea
Scopenote: Members of the 55th Engineer Treadway Bridge Battalion, 1 Corps, construct floating bridge at Han River, Korea during Korean War.

title: Destroyed bridge in Korea
Scopenote: A bridge across the Nam River destroyed by North Koreans during the Korean War.

title: Bridge construction in Korea
Scopenote: A heavily-laden truck is forced to by-pass this bridge on the Suwon-Seoul Highway, one of the spans of the bridge having been only temporarily repaired using crisscrossed railroad ties for support. This was during the Korean War.

title: Destroyed bridge in Korea
Scopenote: Rail bridge destroyed by members of the 65th Engineer Battalion, 25th Infantry Division, during the Korean War.

title: Flood waters by bridge over Han River in Korea
Scopenote: Members of the 185th Engineer Bn., X Corps, fight to save a bridge over the Han River, Korea, north of the X Corps Headquarters, after floating ice and heavy rains caused the river to swell to flood level. This was during the Korean War.

title: Bridge construction in Korea
Scopenote: Men of the 62nd Engineer Battalion drive piles and stack sandbags in the construction of temporary rail bridges across the Han River at Seoul, Korea during the Korean War.

title: Bridge in Korea
Scopenote: Jeep driven across bridge built by 548th Engineer SV BN, 2nd Engineer Construction GP in Korea during Korean War.

title: Apartment buildings damaged by bombing in World War II in Berlin
Scopenote: In a residential section of Berlin, Germany, apartment buildings destroyed or damaged by bombing in World War II, line a street opposite a small river.  Donor:  Barney Ricketts.

title: Bridge in Korea
Scopenote: Bridge built by 548th Engineer SV BN, 2nd Engineer Construction GP in Korea during the Korean War.

title: Bridge in Korea
Scopenote: Bridge built by 548th Engineer SV BN, 2nd Engineer Construction GP in Korea during Korean War.

title: Bridge in Korea
Scopenote: Bridge in Korea during Korean War.

title: South Korean Troops rebuild damaged bridge
Scopenote: South Korean Troops of the 1st Construction Battalion, 2nd Corps, unload steel to be used in rebuilding the Taedong River Bridge, near Pyongyang. The bridge was destroyed by retreating North Korean Forces during heavy fighting in that area.

title: Rebuilding bridge during Korean War
Scopenote: A platoon of B Company, 65th Combat Engineers rebuild a bridge blown up during withdrawal last December of United Nations Army from Suwon, Korea.

title: Bridge in Korea, during Korean War
Scopenote: Bridge in Korea during time of Korean War.

title: Aerial view in Korea
Scopenote: Aerial view in Korea during Korean War.

title: Rycom PIO (Ryukyus Command Public Information Office), Ceremony for New Housing Project in Okinawa
Scopenote: At a ceremony March 26th, Major General Robert S. Beightler, Commanding General, Ryukyus Command and Deputy Governor with Colonel Thomas Lane, Okinawa District Engineer Major E. G. Georgia, DE, Mr. Harry Kim, one of the supervisors of the new project, Mr. M. Notomi, President of the Notomi-Kensetsu Company which will handle the grading and utility installation for the area, and a foreman of the workers on the new housing project Sukiran where 195 dependents dwellings will be built.

title: Rycom PIO (Ryukyus Command Public Information Office), General Simon Buckner Memorial
Scopenote: The Buckner Memorial near Itoman, Okinawa.  Lieutenant General Simon Buckner was killed on this spot during the battle of Okinawa.  As Commander of the American 10th Army, he was watching the progress of the battle.  This memorial has the story engraved in English on one side and Japanese on the other.

title: Voting in Ryukyus in 1950
Scopenote: After more than 1300 years of political reign by Okinawan Kings and subjugation by foreign powers, the people of Ryukyus went to the polls in the fall of 1950 and cast their first free ballot for the candidates of their choice. A new democratic era was ushered in when the inaugurations took place in November, 1950.

title: A street in Berlin lined with buildings and statues destroyed by bombing in World War II
Scopenote: A lone figure and rearing horse are all that remain from statues in a park in Berlin, Germany, showing extensive damage from bombs in World War II.  Across the street and in the background are damaged or destroyed buildings and a church.  Donor:  Barney Ricketts.

title: Rycom PIO (Ryukyus Command Public Information Office), Ryukyus University in Okinawa
Scopenote: Ryukyus University at Shuri, Okinawa.  This is the first higher education plant ever built in the Ryukyus.  President of the university is Koshin Shikiya former "Chiji" of Okinawa.  Additional buildings are presently being constructed under the Civil Administration.

title: Rycom PIO (Ryukyus Command Public Information Office), Housing in Okinawa
Scopenote: One hundred fifty dependent homes are under construction in the Sukiran Tybase area of Okinawa, under the supervision of the District Engineers.  One hundred ninety-five additional homes will be built under contracts to be let.

title: Rycom PIO (Ryukyus Command Public Information Office), Housing in Okinawa
Scopenote: Aerial view of dependent housing area along Route One, approximately one mile north of Naha, Okinawa.  One hundred ninety-eight houses have been contracted for in this area and are being built by the Okinawa District Engineers.  There will be an additional one hundred fifty constructed at a later date.

title: 8th Army Headquarters, Taegu, Korea
Scopenote: 8th Army Headquarters, Taegu, Korea.

title: Sgt. Diale and Cpl. Bessett in Taegu, Korea
Scopenote: Sergeant Diale and Corporal Bessett stand beside General Lowe's jeep at the entrance to 8th Army Headquarters.

title: Major Tyner in Taegu, Korea
Scopenote: Major Tyner, Aide de Camp to Lieutenant General Walker, Commanding General 8th Army.  Taegu, Korea.

title: General Frank E. Lowe and Brigadier General Yu
Scopenote: General Frank E. Lowe and Brigadier General Yu at Headquarters II Corps, R.O.K. in Hayang, Korea. General Yu command II Corps R.O.K., a superior officer, is a graduate of the Japanese Military Academy.

title: General Frank E. Lowe and Others at II Corps Headquarters, Hayang, Korea
Scopenote: Left to right: Lieutenant Doolin, Captain A. G. Hume, General Yu, General Frank E. Lowe, Lieutenant Colonel Rockwell standing in front of the II Corps R.O.K. Headquarters in Hayang, Korea.

title: School house in Pohang Dong, Korea
Scopenote: A school house used by the 3rd R.O.K. Division for their command post in Pohang Dong, Korea.  American Bombers hit the building after the Communists captured Pohang on August 31, 1950.

title: Officers of 3rd Battalion, 9th Infantry Regiment, 2nd Division, Pohang Air Base in Korea
Scopenote: Lieutenant Colonel McMahon, C.O.; Major Boyd, Chaplain; Captain Williams; Major Frazier, Ex. O. and staff officers.  3rd Battalion, 9th Infantry Regiment, 2nd Division, Pohang Air Base in Korea.

title: Buildings in Berlin, Germany, damaged or destroyed by bombing during World War II
Scopenote: Pedestrians walk down a street in Berlin, Germany, lined with buildings destroyed or damaged by bombing during World War II.  Donor:  Barney Ricketts.

title: General Lowe and Others at Pohang Dong, Korea
Scopenote: General Frank E. Lowe, Captain Dupra and Captain A. G. Hume stand before remnants of a village outside of Pohang Dong, Korea.  American artillery accounted for the damage on the previous day.

title: Pohang Dong, Korea
Scopenote: One day after American Bombers and artillery blasted Pohang Dong, Korea, a Catholic Church stands untouched in the background.

title: Headquarters at Angamgni, Korea
Scopenote: Headquarters, Capitol Division, R.O.K. Lieutenant Colonel Paris, Advisor KMAG, Angamgni Korea.

title: I Corps Headquarters in Kyong Ju, Korea
Scopenote: I Corps Headquarters commanded by Major General John H. Coulter in Kyong Ju, Korea during the Korean War.

title: I Corps Headquarters in Kyong Ju, Korea
Scopenote: Entrance to I Corps Headquarters in Kyong Ju, Korea, General John Coulter commanding.  I Corps controls the R.O.K. Capitol Division, 3rd Division and 8th Division.  The United States 21st Infantry was attached for operations.

title: Major General Earle E. Partridge Quarters in Taegu, Korea
Scopenote: Major General Earle E. Partridge Quarters in Taegu, Korea.

title: Western section of Taegu, Korea
Scopenote: Looking down from Major General Earle E. Partridge Quarters.  Korean style huts with straw roofs in the western section of Taegu, Korea.

title: Western section of Korean villages in Taegu
Scopenote: Taken from Major General Earle E. Partridge Quarters overlooking western section of Korean villages in Taegu during the Korean War.

title: Buildings on the Kaiserplatz, Berlin, Germany, damaged by bombing in World War II
Scopenote: On the Kaiserplatz, Berlin, Germany, a church appears unscathed although surrounded by buildings destroyed or damaged by bombing during World War II.  From:  Barney Ricketts, HLS-BOLD Offices, 4400 W. 107th St., Overland Park, Kansas 66207

title: Western section of Korean villages in Taegu, Korea
Scopenote: Taken from Major General Earle E. Partridge Quarters overlooking the western section of Korean villages in Taegu during the Korean War.  Agricultural College in right background.

title: Major General Earle E. Partridge Quarters in Korea
Scopenote: Entrance and driveway leading to Major General Earle E. Partridge Quarters in Taegu, Korea.  South Korean Army Military Police stands guard.

title: Entrance to Major General Earle E. Partridge Quarters in Korea
Scopenote: Inner entrance to Major General Earle E. Partridge Quarters area in Taegu, Korea.  American Flag flying in right background.

title: Sergeant Diale with Taegu, Korea in background
Scopenote: Sergeant Diale standing in the front yard area of Major General Earle E. Partridge Quarters.  Taegu, Korea in background.

title: Sergeant Diale standing by General Frank E. Lowe's Jeep
Scopenote: Sergeant Diale standing by General Frank E. Lowe's Jeep in Taegu, Korea.

title: View of pilot rescue taken from an unarmed plane during Korean War
Scopenote: Taken from an unarmed plane piloted by Captain Edwards, 5th Air Force, during the Korean War. Helicopter (circled to left of wing) rescuing a pilot who had been shot down five miles behind enemy lines. Pilot Captain Robert Wayne bailed out of an F-51 at 1100 feet into a rice paddy.

title: Captain Ray S. White, First Lieutenant Paul VanBoven, Corporal John Fuentz by Helicopter
Scopenote: From left to right: Captain Ray S. White, Air Force, Austin, Texas, P-51 Fighter Pilot, Captain Robert Wayne's wing man. First Lieutenant Paul VanBoven, Air Force, San Mateo, California. Pilot of helicopter that rescued Captain Wayne. Corporal John Fuentz, Para-Medic. Helicopter crew man who pulled Captain Wayne into the helicopter.

title: Captain Edwards and Captain Robert Wayne in Airplane during Korean War
Scopenote: Captain Edwards in front and Captain Robert Wayne in rear after Captain Wayne had been rescued by helicopter. Pohang Air Base, Korea.

title: General Frank E. Lowe's Jeep
Scopenote: General Frank E. Lowe's Jeep parked in front of 1st Cavalry Division Headquarters, six miles northwest of Taegu, Korea.  Major General Hobart (HAP) Gay, Commanding.

title: General Lowe and officers of the 27th British Brigade Headquarters
Scopenote: General Frank E. Lowe confers with Brigadier B. Albrecht Coad, Commander of the 27th Brigade; Mr. Jim Lucas, Scripps Howard correspondent; Mr. Thomas McBeth, Associated Press correspondent; and Captain A. G. Hume at the 27th British Brigade Headquarters in Kang Yong Dong, Korea, along the Nakdong River.

title: Former President Harry S. Truman shakes hands with officers at Fort Lewis, Washington
Scopenote: Former President Harry S. Truman shakes hands with an officer of the 4th Infantry Division at Fort Lewis, Washington, standing with other officers (unidentified) in a receiving line.  Next to Mr. Truman is his 2nd cousin, Major General Louis W. Truman.  The former President was in Seattle, Washington, to attend the Democratic party's annual Jefferson-Jackson Day Banquet.  From:  Major General Louis W. Truman.

title: Buildings on the Kaiserplatz, Berlin, Germany, damaged by bombing in World War II
Scopenote: A view of a church on the Kaiserplatz, Berlin, Germany, miraculously unscathed although surrounded by buildings damaged or destroyed by bombing in World War II.  From:  Barney Ricketts, HLS-BOLD Offices.

title: General Lowe and officers of the 27th British Brigade Headquarters
Scopenote: General Frank E. Lowe; Brigadier B. Albrecht Coad, Commander of the 27th Brigade; Captain A. G. Hume; Mr. Jim Lucas, Scripps Howard correspondent; and Mr. Thomas McBeth, Associated Press correspondent at the 27th British Brigade Headquarters, Kang Yong Dong, Korea. Note camouflaged positions of British vehicles and tents.

title: United States 2nd Division Headquarters
Scopenote: At the United States 2nd Division Headquarters in Hang Hei-ri, Korea, Brigadier General Craig, C.G. 1st Marine Brigade; Major General Laurence B. Keiser, C.G. 2nd Division; and General Frank E. Lowe.

title: Valley overlooking the right flank positions of the 2nd Division during the Korean War
Scopenote: Valley overlooking the right flank positions of the 2nd Division during the Korean War.

title: Officers of 3rd Battalion, 23rd Infantry, 2nd Division Command Post
Scopenote: Left to right:  Lieutenant Truscott, aide de camp to General Bradley; Lieutenant Colonel Robert Scherrard, C.O. 3rd Bn.; Lieutenant Martin Kavanaugh, aide de camp to General Keiser; General Frank E. Lowe; General Bradley, Assistant 2nd Division Commander, at the 3rd Battalion, 23rd Infantry, 2nd Division Command Post in Yongsan, Korea.

title: Russian Machine Guns and Ammunition during Korea War
Scopenote: Lieutenant Martin Kavanaugh, Lieutenant Colonel Robert Scherrard and a South Korean Soldier examine captured Russian type equipment, machine guns and ammunition.

title: Lunch with Colonel C. C. Slone, Jr., and General Frank E. Lowe
Scopenote: At lunch with Colonel C. C. Slone, Jr., Commanding Officer, 9th Infantry Regiment, 2nd Division. Colonel Slone's staff attended lunch with General Frank E. Lowe and Colonel Slone, north of Yongsan, Korea. Colonel Slone and General Lowe are not specifically identified in the group.

title: Captured North Korean prisoner
Scopenote: A North Korean prisoner captured September 6, 1950, by a patrol from the 9th Infantry.  The 16 year old unarmed prisoner had been in the army for twenty days and had not eaten for three days.

title: Russian type submachine gun held by General Frank E. Lowe during Korean War
Scopenote: General Frank E. Lowe holding a Russian type submachine gun, pointing at Model No. 1950, in Yong San, Korea during the Korean War.

title: American tank that was knocked out of action during Korean War
Scopenote: American tank that was knocked out of action by one of the VWO Russian tanks near Yong San, Korea during the Korean War.  A tank retriever crew examine the tank in preparation to return the tank to ordnance for repair.

title: Russian Type T-34 Tanks
Scopenote: Two Russian Type T-34 tanks destroyed by American tanks near Yong San, Korea.  Two America  G.I.'s look over the tanks.  Ridge in the background occupied by front line troops of the 9th Infantry 2nd Division during the Korean War.

title: Buildings in Berlin, Germany, damaged or destroyed by bombing in World War II
Scopenote: Pedestrians go about their business amid a backdrop of buildings destroyed or damaged by bombing during World War II in Berlin, Germany.  From:  Barney Ricketts, HLS-BOLD Offices.

title: General Frank E. Lowe with captured Russian Anti-tank gun during Korean War
Scopenote: General Frank E. Lowe at the 702 Ordinance Company, near Miryang, Korea, with a captured 42 mm anti-tank gun, Russian made, Model 1944, Serial No. 7219.

title: 702nd Ordnance Company Commander in Miryang, Korea
Scopenote: 702nd Ordnance Company Commander stands by three Russian made, Model 1950, 122mm mortars, near Miryang, Korea during the Korean War.

title: Captured equipment during Korean War
Scopenote: General Frank E. Lowe and Captain A. G. Hume look around the captured equipment area at the 702nd Ordnance Company near Miryang, Korea.

title: Captured Russian built truck during Korean War
Scopenote: A captured Russian built truck at the 702nd Ordnance Company near Miryang, Korea during the Korean War.  It was in good running order, brand new tires, 618 miles recorded on the speedometer.

title: Valley near Miryang, Korea
Scopenote: View of valley overlooking right flank area of the United States 2nd Infantry Division near Miryang, Korea during Korean War.

title: Area west of Miryang, Korea
Scopenote: Looking west at Miryang, Korea, surrounded by rice paddies, during Korean War.

title: Marine tank of the 1st Marine Brigade
Scopenote: A Marine tank of the 1st Marine Brigade crossing the Miryang Bridge near Miryang, Korea.  The tanks were on the way to Pusan to load on ship for the Inchon Assault during the Korean War.

title: Captain A. G. Hume, General Frank E. Lowe and Colonel Lowe
Scopenote: General Frank E. Lowe and Colonel Lowe of the 5th Air Force have a little talk.  Captain A. G. Hume is on the left at the 5th Air Force Headquarters near Pusan, Korea.

title: 5th Air Force Headquarters in Pusan, Korea
Scopenote: Entrance to 5th Air Force Headquarters in Pusan, Korea, during Korean War.

title: 5th Air Force Headquarters in Pusan, Korea
Scopenote: Side view of 5th Air Force Headquarters in Pusan, Korea during the Korean War.  The building was formerly used as a college by the South Koreans.

title: A view of Griebritz Lake, Babelsberg, Germany
Scopenote: A view of Griebritz Lake from President Harry S. Truman's residence in Babelsberg, Germany, at the end of World War II.  This is the area where the Potsdam Conference was held.  Donor:  Barney Ricketts.

title: 5th Air Force Ordnance Tent and Motor Vehicle Ramp
Scopenote: 5th Air Force Ordnance tent and motor vehicle ramp during Korean War, probably in Pusan, Korea.  "This is where our Jeep was rebuilt by Major William Booth."

title: Parking lot in front of 5th Air Force Headquarters
Scopenote: Parking lot in front of 5th Air Force Headquarters in Pusan, Korea during the Korean War.

title: South Korean civilians with oxen and carts carrying rice
Scopenote: Civilians with oxen and carts carrying rice for South Korean Army troops near Pusan, Korea.

title: Civilian laborers during Korean War
Scopenote: Civilian laborers working at 5th Air Force Headquarters near Pusan, Korea during Korean War.

title: Civilian women during Korean War
Scopenote: Civilian women helping 5th Air Force personnel repair parking lot at Pusan, Korea during the Korean War.

title: Lieutenant Gene R. Fair, Lieutenant Beers, Major W. Booth, Sergeant Bishop Horton, Sergeant Stephen Elka, in Korea
Scopenote: From left to right: Lieutenant Gene R. Fair, Lieutenant Beers, Major W. Booth, Sergeant Bishop Horton, Sergeant Stephen Elka, all 5th Air Force Personnel.  They were responsible for repairing our Jeep in Pusan, Korea.

title: General Frank E. Lowe, Captain A. G. Hume and Sergeant Diala near Pusan, Korea
Scopenote: Task Force Lowe.  From left to right:  General Frank E. Lowe, Captain A. G. Hume and Sergeant Diala.  Note the .50 caliber machine gun mounted in the Jeep in the background, near Pusan, Korea.

title: Sergeant First Class Diala, General Frank E. Lowe and Captain A. G. Hume
Scopenote: From left to right:  Sergeant First Class Diala, General Frank E. Lowe and Captain A. G. Hume taken just a few minutes before departing 5th Air Force Headquarters for the Pusan Docks near Pusan, Korea, to load aboard the U.S.S. Pickaway.

title: Captain Samuel H. Crittenden, Jr., United States Navy; General Frank E. Lowe; Commander Hugh M. Maples, United States Navy; Major W. Booth; Captain A. G. Hume in Korea
Scopenote: Left to right:  Captain Samuel H. Crittenden, Jr., United States Navy; General Frank E. Lowe; Commander Hugh M. Maples, United States Navy; Major W. Booth; Captain A. G. Hume.  U.S.S. Pickaway in the background near Pusan, Korea.

title: U.S.S. Pickaway during Korean War
Scopenote: U.S.S. Pickaway (A.P.A. 222) near Pusan, Korea prior to departing for Inchon, Korea during the Korean War.

title: Colonel William M. Kasper receives the Silver Star
Scopenote: Colonel William M. Kasper receives the Silver Star from General Wicks, U.S. Army, 4th Division, at a location near Berlin, Germany.  Left to right are:  Colonel William Kasper, Captain Ditamore, General Wicks, Colonel Yuell, and Captain Daly.  From:  Barney Ricketts, HLS-BOLD Offices, 4400 W. 107th St., Overland Park, Kansas 66207

title: Pusan Harbor during Korean War
Scopenote: Taken from the U.S.S. Pickaway, looking northeast across the Pusan Harbor, near Pusan, Korea during the Korean War.

title: South Korean Marines
Scopenote: South Korean Marines wait in very orderly manner to board U.S.S. Pickaway near Pusan, Korea during the Korean War.

title: American Army D.D.T. team spray South Korean Marines
Scopenote: American Army D.D.T. team spray South Korean Marines prior to their loading on ship near Pusan, Korea.

title: South Korean Marines in formation during Korean War
Scopenote: South Korean Marines in formation and waiting to board ship during the Korean War.  Photo taken from the U.S.S. Pickaway by General Frank E. Lowe.

title: United States ships in the Pusan Harbor
Scopenote: United States ships in the Pusan Harbor near Pusan, Korea during the Korean War.  In the center background, a British Hospital Ship sailing into the harbor.

title: The fantail of A.P.A. 222, U.S.S. Pickaway
Scopenote: The fantail of A.P.A. 222, U.S.S. Pickaway, tied up at the Pusan Docks in Pusan, Korea during the Korean War.

title: A group of Marines going aboard the U.S.S. Pickaway
Scopenote: A group of Marines going aboard the U.S.S. Pickaway for lunch near Pusan, Korea during Korean War.

title: Young Marines waiting to board ship during Korean War
Scopenote: Young Marines waiting to board ship for lunch near Pusan, Korea during the Korean War.

title: The U. S. S. Pickaway in Pusan, Korea
Scopenote: The U. S. S. Pickaway, A.P.A. 222, tied up in Pusan, Korea.  The U. S. S. Pickaway proceeded to Inchon for the amphibious landing of the 1st Marine Division.

Scopenote: A group of "B" Battery, 11th Regiment, 1st Marine Division preparing to load on landing ship tank near Pusan, Korea during Korean War.

Scopenote: Landing ship tank Q017 in the harbor near Pusan, Korea, loaded with Marine Corps tanks and ready to sail.

Scopenote: A group of Marines from "A" Battery, 11th Regiment, 1st Marine Division pose for a picture before loading on landing ship tank near Pusan, Korea during the Korean War.

Scopenote: Marines from "B" Battery, 11th Regiment, marching to landing ship tank near Pusan, Korea during the Korean War.

title: Marines from "C" Company, 5th Marine Regiment
Scopenote: Marines from "C" Company, 5th Marine Regiment near Pusan, Korea.  They were the first unit to hit the Inchon Beach, on the 15th of September, 1950.

title: C Company, 5th Marine Regiment during Korean War
Scopenote: C Company, 5th Marine Regiment, waiting to load on ship near Pusan, Korea during the Korean War.

Scopenote: A view of a landing ship tank with ramp open near Pusan, Korea during the Korean War.
